newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Dutch workforce up two percent in 1996 - bureau.
newsitem.headline: Dutch workforce up two percent in 1996 - bureau.

text.p: The number of people in work in The Netherlands grew by 124,000, or about two percent, to 6.187 million in 1996, the Dutch Central Bureau of Statistics (CBS) said on Thursday.
"For the second consecutive year, employment growth was higher than 100,000 jobs," the bureau said.
Employment rose in 1995 and 1996 after minimal growth in the two previous years.
The CBS said Dutch growth rates were favorable compared with other European Union members, which showed an average jobs growth of only 0.2 percent in the 12-months to mid-1996.
But the CBS said the effect on unemployment of the increase in the number of jobs was limited because the number of people looking for work was also rising.

By the end of 1996 about 494,000 people were unemployed, almost 40,000 below the year-earlier level. These numbers include both registered unemployed and those looking for jobs but who have not registered with a labour exchange.
Earlier this month the CBS reported a total of registered unemployed of 432,000 by end-1996.

The CBS said that although the fall in the unemployment total was limited, the trend was still favorable versus Germany, the Netherlands' most important trading partner, where jobless levels rose in 1996.
